Introduction

Bone tumors can be benign or malignant and can arise from any component of bone (eg, marrow, osseous tissue, cartilage, fibrous tissue) (

figure 1
).  The clinical presentation, diagnosis, and management vary, depending on the type of tumor and its location in the bone (eg, diaphysis, metaphysis, epiphysis).

Bone anatomy for tumor classification



Long bones are located in the extremities and consist of:



  • Epiphysis:  The proximal and distal ends of a long bone, adjacent to the joint.
  • Metaphysis:  The flared part of a long bone that extends between the epiphysis and diaphysis.  The metaphysis contains the physis, or growth plate.


  • Diaphysis:  The part of a long bone that extends between the proximal and distal metaphyses in children and epiphyses in adults.

Diagnostic approach to a bone tumor



In cases of a suspected bone tumor, diagnostic evaluation includes the following:



  • History and physical examination.
  • Imaging:  Plain radiograph is the initial imaging modality.  MRI/CT scan may be necessary to determine the extent of cortical and soft tissue involvement, especially if management requires surgical resection.
  • Biopsy with histopathology confirms the diagnosis.


This article focuses on the most common bone tumors, which are classified by their location in long bones.  Metastatic and hematologic (eg, lymphoma, multiple myeloma) malignancies that affect the bone marrow are not discussed in this article and can be found in separate dedicated articles.

Epiphyseal bone tumors

Giant cell tumor of bone



Giant cell tumor of bone (GCTB) is a benign but locally destructive osteolytic epiphyseal bone tumor that arises from osteoclastic precursor cells.



  • Epidemiology:  GCTB most commonly occurs in young adults who have reached skeletal maturity (age 20-40).
  • Location:  GCTB most commonly occurs at the epiphyses of the distal femur and proximal tibia.
  • Clinical presentation:  The presentation varies but often involves localized pain, swelling, stiffness, and pathologic fracture (ie, fracture with minor trauma).  The range of motion of the affected joint may be diminished.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal an eccentric, expansive lytic lesion with a "soap bubble" appearance due to intralesional bony trabeculae (
    image 1
    ).  MRI may be necessary for evaluating the extent of adjacent soft tissue involvement.
  • Pathology:  GCTB is composed of multinucleated, osteoclast-like giant cells that are interspersed with mononuclear stromal cells (
    image 2
    ).  Stromal cells overexpress the receptor activator of nuclear factor-kappa B ligand (RANKL), a protein that induces the activation and differentiation of osteoclasts.
  • Management:  Surgery (eg, intralesional curettage or excision) with reconstruction is first-line therapy.  Denosumab, a monoclonal antibody that inhibits RANKL (ie, inhibits osteoclast activation), may be considered for unresectable tumors.
  • Prognosis:  The prognosis is generally favorable, although the risk for local recurrence is high, especially in cases of incomplete excision.  Rarely, malignant transformation and pulmonary metastasis can occur.

Chondroblastoma



Chondroblastoma is a benign cartilage-producing epiphyseal bone tumor.



  • Epidemiology:  Chondroblastoma most commonly occurs in adolescents and young adults (age 10-21) who have not reached skeletal maturity.  Chondroblastoma is more common in male patients.
  • Location:  Chondroblastoma most commonly occurs at the epiphyses of the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.
  • Clinical presentation:  The presentation involves constant localized joint pain and swelling.  Range of motion may be diminished.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal a well-circumscribed radiolucent lesion with a thin sclerotic border that may cross the physis (
    image 3
    ).  Calcifications may be present.
  • Pathology:  Chondroblastoma is composed of immature chondroblasts, osteoblast-like giant cells, and chondroid matrix (ie, cartilaginous tissue produced by tumor cells that often contains calcifications).
  • Management:  Surgery (ie, curettage) with reconstruction is performed.
  • Prognosis:  The prognosis is generally favorable, although physis involvement can lead to growth arrest and joint involvement can lead to arthritis.  Local recurrence can occur.

Diaphyseal bone tumors

Ewing sarcoma



Ewing sarcoma is a malignant osteolytic diaphyseal bone tumor, likely arising from neuroectodermal or mesenchymal stem cells (

).



  • Epidemiology:  Ewing sarcoma is the second most common malignant bone tumor in children and adolescents (after osteosarcoma (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    )), with a peak incidence at age 10-15.
  • Location:  Ewing sarcoma most commonly occurs at the diaphyses of the long bones, but the pelvis and axial skeleton can also be affected.
  • Clinical presentation:  The presentation involves chronic, localized pain and swelling that may limit physical activity (eg, walking up stairs).  Pain is often worse at night and with activity, and it progresses rapidly.  Systemic findings (eg, fever, fatigue) may be present and are concerning for metastatic disease.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal a central lytic lesion with a mottled ("moth-eaten") appearance that infiltrates the bony cortex and adjacent soft tissue.  The associated periosteal reaction leads to concentric layers of new, reactive bone (ie, "onion skinning") (
    image 4
    ).  MRI may be necessary for evaluating the extent of adjacent soft tissue and vascular involvement.
  • Pathology:  Ewing sarcoma is a primitive tumor that likely arises from neuroectodermal or mesenchymal stem cells.  Histopathology shows sheets of uniform small, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm separated by fibrous septa and patches of necrosis (
    image 5
    ).  Most cases are associated with translocations involving EWSR1 on chromosome 22 and FLI1 on chromosome 11 [ie, a t(11;22) translocation].  This translocation produces a fusion protein that functions as an abnormal transcription factor, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation.
  • Management:  Treatment involves chemotherapy with local control via surgical resection and/or radiation therapy.
  • Prognosis:  Ewing sarcoma often metastasizes to the lungs, and pulmonary complications (eg, hemoptysis) are a leading cause of death.  The 5-year survival rate is approximately 70% for patients with localized disease and approximately 33% for patients with metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis.

Osteoid osteoma



Osteoid osteoma is a benign diaphyseal bone-forming tumor (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).



  • Epidemiology:  Osteoid osteoma most commonly occurs in adolescent boys.
  • Location:  Osteoid osteoma most commonly occurs in the lower extremities, particularly the proximal femur and tibia.  The spine can also be affected.
  • Clinical presentation:  The presentation involves chronic, localized pain that is worse at night, unrelated to physical activity, and relieved by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).  Most patients have no systemic symptoms or focal examination findings.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal a small, round lucency with sclerotic margins (
    image 6
    ).  Central ossification may be present.
  • Pathology:  Histopathology shows a central nidus with osteoblasts and an osteoid (ie, unmineralized tissue composed of type I collagen) matrix surrounded by osteoclastic activity (ie, central lucency).  The central nidus produces high levels of prostaglandins, causing inflammation and pain.
  • Management:  NSAIDs (which inhibit prostaglandins) are prescribed and serial radiographs performed to monitor growth.  Surgical resection may be considered for patients who cannot tolerate long-term NSAID use.
  • Prognosis:  Spontaneous resolution occurs within years of diagnosis.


Osteoblastoma is a similar benign bone-forming tumor that may share the same underlying genetic etiology as osteoid osteoma.  Osteoblastoma most commonly occurs in the spine, followed by the diaphyses of the long bones.  In general, the pain associated with osteoblastoma is less responsive to NSAIDs, and the central nidus is larger in comparison to osteoid osteoma.

Metaphyseal bone tumors

Osteosarcoma



Osteosarcoma is a malignant osteoblastic metaphyseal bone tumor thought to arise in mesenchymal stem cells or osteoblastic progenitor cells (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
).



  • Epidemiology:  Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in children and adolescents and occurs in a bimodal distribution (ie, age <25 and >50).  This malignant transformation occurs mostly during the rapid growth phase of long bones (ie, adolescence) but can also be due to hereditary genetic mutations (eg, RB1, TP53).
  • Location:  Osteosarcoma most commonly occurs at the metaphyses of the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.
  • Clinical presentation:  Chronic, localized pain is dull and progressive over weeks to months.  Physical examination shows tenderness and swelling, often with a palpable soft tissue mass.  Depending on the location and extent of joint involvement, patients may demonstrate a decreased range of motion or an abnormal gait.  Systemic symptoms are rare and may indicate advanced disease when present.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal an ill-defined lesion with a mixture of radiolucent (ie, osteolytic) and radiodense (ie, osteoblastic) areas within the metaphysis of a long bone (
    image 7
    ), often with a "sunburst" periosteal reaction that is characterized by ossification of fragmented fibers perpendicular to the bone.
  • Pathology:  Histopathology shows malignant cells resembling osteoblasts of varying size (ie, pleomorphic) with atypical nuclei and irregular, lace-like osteoid (
    image 8
    ).
  • Management:  Management involves chemotherapy and surgical resection.
  • Prognosis:  The prognosis depends on the stage at presentation.  Whereas patients with localized disease have a favorable outcome with prompt diagnosis and treatment, those with metastases have a poor prognosis.

Fibrosarcoma



Fibrosarcoma is a malignant tumor that arises from metaphyseal fibrous connective tissue.



  • Epidemiology:  Fibrosarcoma is rare and most commonly affects middle-aged adults.
  • Location:  Fibrosarcoma most commonly occurs at the metaphyses of the long bones, particularly the femur, tibia, and humerus.
  • Clinical presentation:  Localized pain and swelling are present.  Pathologic fracture may occur.  There may be a history of preexisting bone lesions (eg, irradiated tissue) that predispose to fibrosarcoma.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal a localized osteolytic lesion that infiltrates the cortex and adjacent soft tissues with minimal periosteal reaction.
  • Pathology:  Histopathology shows spindle cells (cells with scant cytoplasm and elongated, hyperchromatic nuclei) arranged in a herringbone pattern (
    image 9
    ).
  • Management:  Treatment involves chemotherapy and surgical resection.
  • Prognosis:  The prognosis is unfavorable due to a high risk for recurrence and metastasis.

Unicameral bone cyst



Unicameral bone cyst, also known as a simple or solitary bone cyst, is a benign, fluid-filled lesion with a fibrous membrane (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
).



  • Epidemiology:  Unicameral bone cysts most commonly occur in skeletally immature children and adolescents.
  • Location:  Unicameral bone cysts most commonly develop in the metaphyses of long bones, particularly the proximal humerus and femur.
  • Clinical presentation:  Most patients are asymptomatic, and the lesion is found incidentally on imaging.  Patients rarely present with pain due to a pathologic fracture.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal a well-defined lucency with a thin sclerotic margin (
    image 10
    ).  MRI shows a homogeneous, fluid-filled lesion (ie, cyst) with an enhancing rim.  There is no periosteal reaction.
  • Management:  Treatment involves observation with serial radiographs until spontaneous resolution, typically after the patient reaches skeletal maturity (ie, physis closes).
  • Prognosis:  Spontaneous resolution occurs in most cases, so the prognosis is favorable.

Osteochondroma



Osteochondroma is a benign metaphyseal bone tumor composed of bone with a cartilaginous cap (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
).



  • Epidemiology:  Osteochondroma is the most common benign bone tumor.  Adolescents and young adults (age 10-20) are most often affected.
  • Location:  Osteochondroma most commonly develops in or proximal to the metaphysis and extends away from the epiphysis.
  • Clinical presentation:  Patients may be asymptomatic or present with a hard, painless nodule near a joint.  If asymptomatic, the lesion is often found incidentally on imaging.  In advanced cases, local compression of neurovascular structures may cause pain, but systemic features (eg, fever, weight loss) are rare.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal well-defined metaphyseal bony outgrowth with a pedunculated base that grows away from the epiphysis (ie, toward the diaphysis) and has continuity with the cortices and medullae of adjacent bones (
    image 11
    ).
  • Pathology:  Histopathology shows bone with a cartilaginous cap.
  • Management:  Osteochondroma stops growing when the patient reaches skeletal maturity.  Most lesions remain static through adulthood and are typically managed with observation alone.
  • Prognosis:  The risk for malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma in adulthood is very low (~1%) for a solidary lesion; therefore, the prognosis is favorable.

Chondrosarcoma



Chondrosarcoma is a malignant metaphyseal cartilage-producing bone tumor.



  • Epidemiology:  Chondrosarcoma most commonly occurs in adults age >40.
  • Location:  Chondrosarcoma most commonly develops in the metaphyses of long bones, particularly the proximal humerus and femur, and the pelvis.
  • Clinical presentation:  Localized pain and swelling are involved.  Pain is insidious and progressive, often present for months to years prior to diagnosis.  Pathologic fractures may occur.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal radiolucent and radiodense areas with intralesional calcifications in a ring-and-arc pattern (
    image 12
    ).  Calcifications may coalesce to form a radiopaque lesion.
  • Pathology:  Histopathology shows atypical chondrocytes with abundant chondroid matrix (
    image 13
    ).
  • Management:  The treatment involves surgical resection.  Chemotherapy may be considered for patients with unresectable (eg, metastatic) disease but is generally not effective.
  • Prognosis:  The prognosis is favorable if complete resection is achieved.  Surveillance for local recurrence should be performed.

Enchondroma



Enchondroma is a benign metaphyseal cartilage-producing bone tumor.



  • Epidemiology:  Enchondroma most commonly occurs in adolescents and young adults.
  • Location:  Enchondroma most commonly develops in the metaphyses of long bones, particularly the hand, humerus, and femur.
  • Clinical presentation:  Most patients are asymptomatic, and the lesion is found incidentally on imaging.  Rarely, patients present with pain due to a pathologic fracture,  a gross deformity, or a leg length discrepancy.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal a well-circumscribed lesion with central lucency.  Central calcifications and sclerotic margins may be present.
  • Pathology:  Histopathology shows chondrocytes with abundant chondroid and punctate calcifications.
  • Management:  The tumor is observed, and surgical resection is performed if there are risk factors for pathologic fracture (eg, large size, location in weight-bearing bone).
  • Prognosis:  Spontaneous resolution occurs in most patients.  Rare complications include local recurrence and malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma.

Nonossifying fibroma



Nonossifying fibroma is a benign metaphyseal developmental defect characterized by fibrous connective tissue (ie, no bone).



  • Epidemiology:  Nonossifying fibroma most commonly occurs in adolescents and young adults.
  • Location:  Nonossifying fibroma most commonly develops in the metaphyses of long bones, particularly the femur and tibia.
  • Clinical presentation:  Most patients are asymptomatic, and the lesion is found incidentally on imaging.  Rarely, patients present with pain due to a pathologic fracture.
  • Imaging:  Radiographs reveal a well-circumscribed lytic lesion.
  • Pathology:  Histopathology shows fibrous connective tissue with no bone.
  • Management:  Management involves observation, and surgical resection is performed if there are risk factors for pathologic fracture (eg, large size, location in weight-bearing bone).
  • Prognosis:  Spontaneous resolution (ie, fibrous connective tissue replaced with normal bone) occurs in most patients.  Rare complications include local recurrence and malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma.

Bone tumors in other locations



Common bone tumors that can present in other locations include:



  • Fibrous dysplasia:  This benign lesion is characterized by fibrous connective tissue with irregular trabecular bone.  Fibrous dysplasia can occur in any bone, most commonly the femur, tibia, ribs, and skull of adolescents and young adults.  Patients are often asymptomatic, and radiographs reveal a lytic lesion with a homogenous (ie, ground-glass) appearance.  Fibrous dysplasia in multiple bones is concerning for McCune-Albright syndrome (
    image 14
    ), which classically presents with the triad of fibrous dysplasia, endocrine abnormalities, and cafÃ© au lait spots.
  • Aneurysmal bone cyst:  This benign vascular lesion can occur in any bone, most commonly in adolescents.  Aneurysmal bone cysts can cause localized pain and swelling and may grow rapidly.  Radiographs reveal a lytic lesion with a thin sclerotic rim.  Because aneurysmal bone cysts are aggressive, surgical resection is required to preserve adjacent bone and prevent pathologic fracture.

Summary



Bone tumors can be benign (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 7
) or malignant and can arise from any component of bone (eg, osseous tissue, cartilage, fibrous tissue, marrow).  The clinical presentation, diagnosis, and management vary, depending on the type of tumor and its location within the bone (eg, diaphysis, metaphysis, epiphysis).  Characteristic radiologic and histopathologic features can confirm the diagnosis.  Prompt evaluation and management, often involving a multidisciplinary team, are essential for optimizing patient outcomes.
